instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message:
Have a liquid damage board here that stay in s0 mode.

i`m missing <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVITT</SIGNAL>

on <CHIP>U7300</CHIP> measuring volts:

Pin 1) 0V
Pin 2 1,5V
Pin 3) 0V
Pin 5) 0,75V
Pin 6) 1,79V
Pin 8) 1,49V
Pin 9) 1,52V
Pin 11) 0,10V
pin12) 5,05V
pin 13) 1,50V
pin14) 1,50V
pin15) 6,55V
pin16) 3,32V
pin17) 0V
pin18) 0,96V
pin19) 0V
pin20) 096V

can someone point me too next step?

threads.message:
Think maybe the cpu ton resistor is fucked up. 

in diode mode i get 5,82M ohm (red on ground)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message: How can you measure the TON resistor with a probe on GND? You measure the resistance on both pins of the resistor.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message: Sorry my fault. It is 6.44M ohm booth side

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message: Seems you didnt understand yet.. Red probe on pin 1 and black probe on pin 2 from <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>!! If it is truly 6.44M then the resistor is pretty fucked up!!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message: I understand. The resistor is pretty fucked up :)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stay in s0 mode
threads.message:
have replace 7402 and have the  right ohm (90,6K) and have 3.31V <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 

no chime and no screen

and on CPU Vcore i have 0.77V
